page.title: 03BISLEY'S FAMOUS PEOPLE
page.content: The most famous resident was Rev. Thomas Keble, brother to the founder of the Keble Oxford Movement. He was vicar of Bisley from 1827 to 1873 and was a great builder for the church. By 1862 he had entirely restored The Church of All Saints in Bisley, built a church at Bussage, at France Lynch and at Eastcombe. He was also responsible for building schools at Bisley, Oakridge, Bussage, Eastcombe and France Lynch. His son also called Thomas, succeeded him and was responsible for the legend of the "Bisley Boy".Workmen excavating the site for the new village school came across a medieval stone coffin in which were the bones of a girl. The remains were reputed to be those of Elizabeth I who died while staying at Overcourt. It is said that she was replaced by a boy and so never married
